content.title: Oitavos Dunes, the crème de la crème of golf courses

introduction.small: Regularly ranked as one of the top 100 most beautiful courses in the world, Oitavos Dunes enjoys superb surroundings and an inspired design.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Oitavos Dunes, the crème de la crème of golf courses

paragraphs.text:
The Sintra-Cascais Natural Park is home to the Oitavos Dunes, a golf course known and loved by golfers around the world. Wherever you find yourself amidst the bunkers and umbrella pines of this 18-hole course, you will be treated to stunning views of the Atlantic Ocean, and if you look towards Cabo da Roca – Europe's westernmost point – you will even be able to make out the outline of the Sintra Mountains.

This masterpiece of land, sand and lawn was meticulously designed in the early 2000s by Arthur Hills, one of the greatest golf course architects of our time, who made a point of ensuring that the 6,303m course blended seamlessly with the natural beauty of its surroundings.

Seasoned golfers can choose between a golf day package or overnight stay at the club's 5-star hotel, The Oitavos, located at the heart of the complex. There are also plenty of facilities on site for learning the secrets of this captivating sport from the best teachers around: specialists who demand self-control, patience, and precision.

 

Oitavos Dunes
Quinta da Marinha, Lote 64
2750-040 Cascais

+351 21 486 0600

https://oitavosdunes.com

content.title: SEEN Lisboa, the must-see hotspot

introduction.small: Up on the ninth floor of the Tivoli Avenida Liberdade Hotel, SEEN is a staple of Lisbon's nightlife and growing more popular by the minute.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: SEEN Lisboa, the must-see hotspot

paragraphs.text:
As you step out of the lift, your gaze is immediately drawn to the incredible circular bar: the realm of chief mixologist Lucas Jaques. It surrounds the trunk of an artificial tree, with branches reaching all the way up to the ceiling.

A giant sofa snakes through the Art Deco room, which harks back to the golden days of the 1930s, winding its way to the vast bay window where a breath-taking view over the Tagus, the Baixa neighbourhood and the Castelo de São Jorge awaits.

The menu is a masterpiece by French-Portuguese chef Olivier Da Costa, featuring modern cuisine with subtle Portuguese influences. Start with truffle, Parmesan and chive linguine, followed by octopus carpaccio with red pepper and tomato. To finish, we recommend the papos de anjo, a new twist on a classic dessert of passion fruit, mascarpone, and coconut. The dining options at SEEN are some of the most comprehensive in Lisbon: there is also a sushi bar and an oyster bar serving some of Portugal's finest. From Monday to Saturday evening, a DJ brings the place alive with the sizzling sound of house and electro, with the pumping music making the views over Lisbon even more magical!

SEEN Lisboa Restaurant & Bar
Hôtel Tivoli Avenida Liberdade Lisboa (9th floor)
Avenida da Liberdade 185
1269-050 Lisbon

Tel : +351 91 467 3356

http://seenlx.com

Menu: around 40 EUR (cocktails from 10 EUR)

content.title: Quinta do Pisão, getting back to nature

introduction.small: Welcome to Quinta do Pisão: the perfect place to immerse yourself in the day-to-day of a traditional farm and enjoy the beauty of one of Portugal's 13 natural parks.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Quinta do Pisão, getting back to nature

paragraphs.text:
The Quinta do Pisão estate lies 30km west of Lisbon, and welcomes visitors free of charge who want to explore one of the many working farms still scattered through the region.

All around the 380-hectare agri-silvicultural and dairy farm, information boards tell you about the history of the land, as well as the wildlife you will come across during your walk or cycle ride. Filled with rich vegetation, the Sintra-Cascais Natural Park is home to all sorts of wild animals, including grey herons, common buzzards, genets and foxes.

At Quinta do Pisão, you will also get to meet the farm's Asinina Mirandesa donkeys and Alentejo sheep. After your tour, which focuses mainly on environmental issues and conservation, you will be offered a basket of organic vegetables grown in the farm's kitchen garden to take home with you. Little ones can enjoy a donkey ride, too - it promises to be a fun day out!

Quinta do Pisão
Parque Natural de Sintra-Cascais
Estrada EN9-1
Cascais

+351 21 581 1750

https://www.facebook.com/Quinta-do-Pisão-102741224625473/?ref=page_internal

content.title: Zazah, the art of after-work drinks

introduction.small: Opened in 2017 by three young Brazilians, this restaurant is never empty come home time for the city's office workers. The secret? Good food, good conversation, and excellent company.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zazah, the art of after-work drinks

paragraphs.text:
Once known for its antique shops and public gardens, the last few years have seen Príncipe Real become one of the coolest neighbourhoods of the Portuguese capital. Of the myriad bars and boutiques that have sprung up in recent times though, Zazah stands head and shoulders above the lot. Once you see the 25 de Abril Bridge and the outline of the Sanctuary of Christ the King looming above the Tagus in the distance, you will have arrived at the temple of fine dining.

In the kitchen is chef Moisés Franco, a former assistant to none other than José Avillez, and traditional dishes with a Brazilian carioca twist take centre stage. Ingredients are local and organic, and food is served on large sharing platters. Prepare to be wowed by the Iberian pork lagarto with chimichurri and lime - unless of course you go for the creamy black truffle purée! The atmosphere is pleasantly laid-back, with a wine list and expertly made cocktails to choose from. As the evening goes on, the restaurant grows louder and louder, until a DJ appears and Zazah transforms into a dancefloor!

 

Zazah
Rua de São Marçal 111
1200-420 Lisboa

+351 21 134 4468

www.zazah.pt/?lang=en

Menu: around 34 EUR

content.title: Audaz, bold flavours

introduction.small: At once bar and restaurant with a gastronomic trend, Audaz lives by its name (“bold” in English) and tries out new flavours inspired by its local roots.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Audaz, bold flavours

paragraphs.text:
A village within the city, a residential district left alone by tourists who should know better… This is the spot that real connoisseurs favour, far from the Mouraria and Intendente trendiest fare. One has to say that Campo de Ourique reveals itself fully to the most dedicated only. Audaz is undeniably one of its hidden secrets, already a success in spite of its young age. Launched in 2020, this gastropub is renowned for various reasons: as an after-work holdout in the neighbourhood with Audaz O'Clock, the establishment takes pride in the various creative experiences that take place behind the counter until late into the night.

When it comes to the food, the recipes of chef Manuel Lino (who learnt the ropes in Europe's most famous restaurants, including Spanish three-star El Celler de Can Roca in Girona) attract even the most demanding of local food lovers. He draws inspiration in traditional Portuguese cuisine to create contemporary specialities that remain just as bold. Several dishes on the menu are meant to be shared, including the incredibly hard-to-make smoked jack mackerel (a very popular fish in Portugal), served with a fishbone and grilled lemon sauce. Feeling like vegetables? Then order the roasted eggplant, inspired by Azores cuisine but with an added twist: low-temperature cooked egg, garlic, and sundried tomatoes. We did say bold, did we not?

Audaz Gastropub
Rua 4 de Infantaria 3A
Campo de Ourique
1350-266 Lisboa

+351 21 134 9094

https://www.audazgastropub.pt

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: Crispy Mafya, an ode to fried chicken

introduction.small: In between bars of Lisbon's trendy Príncipe Real, Crispy Mafya draws from New Orleans street food: fried chicken is king.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Crispy Mafya, an ode to fried chicken

paragraphs.text:
At the crossroad of cultures, Crispy Mafya set up home amid Lisbon's Príncipe Real, one of the trendiest neighbourhoods of the capital with its designer, fashion, and home decoration boutiques. It is also famous for its nightlife.

Initiated by two French brothers who drew from New Orleans street food, it makes fried chicken the main and recurring ingredient of all dishes on the menu. Farm raised in the Alentejo region south of Lisbon, it is then fried and served in a range of different recipes: wings, burgers, in a cone (the Chiken'N Kone is already a classic) and even with homemade waffles.

Just like the chicken, the rest of the ingredients used at Crispy Mafya is local, and most everything is made on the spot, including sauces. Denizens of the area usually order their tenders as takeaway, best enjoyed under the cedar trees of the Príncipe Real garden located a few metres away from the restaurant. Alternately, they take a seat at one of the tables for lunch, and share a few chicken wings and a cocktail in an atmosphere suffused with hip hop.

Crispy Mafya
Rua Cecílio de Sousa 85
1200-100 Lisboa

+351 21 400 3108

https://www.facebook.com/crispymafya/

Menu: around 19 EUR

content.title: Gastronomic hotchpotch at Time Out Market Lisbon

introduction.small: Entertainment and events guide Time Out has launched a food market in Lisbon, gathering a selection of the city's best restaurants in the Mercado da Ribeira food hall.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gastronomic hotchpotch at Time Out Market Lisbon

paragraphs.text:
Review after review, the weekly magazine Time Out has outlined an extensive view of Lisbon's gastronomic offer. In 2014, the articles compiling the very best of the local food scene magically turned into a trendy food hall. Nestled in the Mercado da Ribeira covered market on the banks of the Tagus, Time Out Market Lisbon shelters about 50 different food stalls. Traditional Portuguese dishes, fusion food, burgers, Japanese gastronomy, pastries and even a wine bar… Time Out's selection is spread around large wooden tables that are ideal to friendly share a meal. Besides offering the best restaurant food, the covered market also holds concerts, exhibitions, conferences and even cooking classes. Even though the location is very popular among locals and attracts more than million visitors each year, you will always find a table as it is open from 10 a.m. to 10:30 p.m. seven days a week. The success of this culinary adventure in Lisbon has led the way to other Time Out markets opening around the world since!

Time out Market Lisbon
Mercado da Ribeira
Avenida 24 de Julho 49
1200-479 Lisboa

+351 21 395 1274

https://www.timeoutmarket.com/lisboa/en/

content.title: Life of Riley at The One Palacio da Anunciada

introduction.small: Near the Praça dos Restauradores and the Glória funicular, The One by H10 Hotels group, with premises already in Barcelona, has moved into the Palácio da Anunciada, a 16th-century Lisbon palace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Life of Riley at The One Palacio da Anunciada

paragraphs.text:
A genuine witness of Lisbon's history, the Palácio da Anunciada has had several lives. Its new incarnation turns this 16th-century Portuguese monument into a five-star hotel of The One by H10 group. The renovation has retained the spirit originally infused by Fernão Alves de Andrade (also benefactor of the Our Lady of the Annunciation Church that gave its name to the palace). The Renaissance style of the premises is to be found in the original ceilings and vast gardens (about 2,500 sqm) that shelter a preserved century-old dragon tree. They are now augmented with an outdoor swimming pool lined with Balinese beds. A second pool was installed inside the palace, as well as a spa and sauna. As for the bedrooms, most of which overlook the gardens, period pomp has taken a modern shift. Egyptian cotton sheets on the beds, hand-painted blue and white ceramics on whitened walls… these are just a sample of the 21st-century life of Riley that awaits.

The One Palácio da Anunciada
Rua das Portas de Santo Antão 112-134
1150-268 Lisboa

+351 21 041 2300

https://www.hotelstheone.com/en/lisboa

Rooms: from 192 EUR

content.title: Lisboa Story Centre, time travelling machine

introduction.small: From its construction during the Phoenician era to the major events of modern history, immerse yourself in the city's past at the Lisboa Story Centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lisboa Story Centre, time travelling machine

paragraphs.text:
Have you always heard of the 1755 earthquake without realizing how deeply it modified the look of the Portuguese capital? In that case, head to the Praça do Comércio – one of the largest city squares – where you will find the lovely ochre façade of the Lisboa Story Centre. Using an audio guide (in English, French, Portuguese or Spanish) and the latest interactive equipment based on 3D technology, you will be able to witness and feel the impact of the terrible earthquake. Be ready for waves of different emotions as the city, almost entirely destroyed, is slowly rebuilt before your eyes!

Divided into six main sections, the Lisboa Story Centre unveils all the secrets of the “City of Seven Hills”, from its construction during the Phoenician era to our modern times. Full-scale decors, photographs, animated videos and even holograms will plunge you into a moving exploration of the capital's past.

Lisboa Story Centre
Terreiro do Paço 78-81
1100-148 Lisboa

+351 21 194 1027

https://www.lisboastorycentre.pt/en/content/lisboa-story-centre

content.title: Tailor-made Portuguese wine experience in Lisbon and Alentejo

introduction.small: Discover historic Lisbon and the nearby UNESCO World Heritage sites on a four-day tour of the wine region of Alentejo

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tailor-made Portuguese wine experience in Lisbon and Alentejo

paragraphs.text:
Begin your adventure with a bespoke tour of the country's eclectic capital, Lisbon. Explore its famed hills on the historic yellow trams that climb the steep slopes and take in the sunset over the magnificent Tejo. Then head to the Bairro Alto to experience the soulful musical tradition of Fado and try the sophisticated yet traditional cuisine.

Journey out along the Tejo to Belém to taste the famed custard tarts, Pastéis de Belém, discover its spectacular Hieronymites Monastery and see where Henry the Navigator set sail for the New World.

Head inland to wander the winding, narrow streets of picturesque UNESCO World Heritage site and Cultural Landscape Sintra, its romantic palaces and shady paths, before relaxing at a local winery to sample its range of award-winning wines.

Stay overnight in a five-star hotel in stunning medieval Évora, stroll around the walled historic centre overlooking the rolling plains, and admire the vast vineyards and cork plantations of Alentejo.

Spend your final day at organic estate of Herdade do Esporão. Take a cellar tour, visit its olive press and marvel at its ancient cork trees stripped of their bark. Finally, indulge in an exquisite lunch paired with their superb Portuguese wines, to be enjoyed in moderation.

Hieronymites Monastery
Praça do Império
1400-206 Lisboa
+351 21 362 0034
http://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/en/museus-e-monumentos/dgpc/m/mosteiro-dos-jeronimos/

Wine Paths
+33 (0)5 57 78 43 47
Discover more about this Lisbon and Alentejo wine tour:

https://www.winepaths.com/expert/portugal/joao/4-day-lisbon-and-alentejo-package

content.title: Gastronomical journey at Taberna Fina

introduction.small: A unique tasting menu in ten steps that will instantly make you want to come back!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gastronomical journey at Taberna Fina

paragraphs.text:
On the second floor of Le Consulat hotel in the Chiado neighbourhood, Taberna Fina plays the part of gastronomical inn. If chef André Magalhães puts the emphasis on the quality of typically Portuguese products that are always fresh and seasonal, he does not limit himself to national cuisine. His dishes are unpretentiously suffused with worldwide influences, especially from Latin America.
Seating twenty amid dark colour walls and art photos, it plunges you in Lisbon's most intimate side. The menu will not be revealed before being served and changes constantly – it is strongly advised to warn the restaurant beforehand in case of food allergies. The gastronomical journey goes on through ten exceptional culinary milestones: three pre-dinner nibbles, an appetiser, a starter, a fish dish, another one with meat, a cheeseboard served with on-demand jams and then two desserts… as well as mini-pastries to round it off. Let yourself be led and take time to enjoy!

Taberna Fina
Praça Luis de Camões, 22
1200-243 Lisbonne

+351 938 596 429

www.leconsulat.pt/taberna-fina/ ﻿

Tasting menu: 56 EUR

content.title: Santa Clara 1728, Lisbon's most minimalist address

introduction.small: Hidden behind the Alfama neighbourhood and committed to an eco-friendly approach, the Santa Clara 1728 turns out to be the ideal urban retreat for body and mind to rest.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Santa Clara 1728, Lisbon's most minimalist address

paragraphs.text:
In this 18th-century building, six luxurious rooms have been imagined and conceived by famous Lisbon architect Manuel Aires Mateus, who, moved by principles of sustainable development, used only natural materials like marble, wood and stone. In a stripped-down decor, where minimalist furniture stands alongside Baroque paintings laid directly on the floor, all rooms at Santa Clara 1728 offer unobstructed views over the Tagus River. Even the bathrooms play the authenticity card, with hand-crafted tiling and terra cotta bathtubs.
You will not find an official restaurant in this elegant hotel, but a gigantic guesthouse evening meal instead, where food is prepared on demand. Under the large arches and subdued lighting, you will be able to indulge in Lisbon's typical cuisine. Do not pass by the traditional arroz doce, a rice pudding with a sweetness that will stick in your memory for a long time.
This haven of rest is well hidden, therefore perfect for discreet stays.

Santa Clara 1728
Campo de Santa Clara 128
1100-473 Lisboa

+351 93 436 2816

https://www.silentliving.pt/houses/santa-clara-1728/

content.title: Prado, a little bit of nature on the plate

introduction.small: Large spaces, a Nordic style and a friendly atmosphere await at Prado, in the heart of Lisbon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Prado, a little bit of nature on the plate

paragraphs.text:
A fresh wind blows on the Travessa das Pedras Negras. Step in and plunge into a most bucolic atmosphere. Masses of plants overhang the main dining area, and the large windows allow the restaurant to be bathed in natural light.
Young chef Antonio Galapito makes wonders with regional produce. Fish is caught in the night or early morning, and vegetables are supplied by small local producers. Dishes are refined and displayed in natural stoneware.
Try the black scabbardfish (a local delicacy) with nasturtiums and homegrown radishes, or succumb to the temptation of Iberian pork tenderloin with quince and chocolate pepper. For dessert, opt for goat cheese curds with fennel and clementine granita. A surprising spot to be tried without delay!

Prado Restaurante
Travessa das Pedras Negras 2
1100-404 Lisboa

+351 21 053 4649

https://www.pradorestaurante.com/

Menu: from 30 EUR

content.title: City break at 1908 Lisboa Hotel

introduction.small: Spend a marvellous night in this hotel and plunge into Lisbon's authentic side.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: City break at 1908 Lisboa Hotel

paragraphs.text:
The year 1908 saw the birth of a Lisbon house, which in turn became an inn, and then a business, until it was relived in 2017 to become a gorgeous hotel.
Located in the trendy Intendente neighbourhood, the 1908 Lisboa Hotel cultivates attention to details. This charming hotel retained the ancient characteristics of the building, whilst adding modern equipment and contemporary touches. Artur Bordalo, one of today's most praised street artists, has devised a piece exclusively for the 1908 Lisboa Hotel - to be discovered in the lobby. Gorgeous furniture, rich fabrics and natural colour patterns all create a comfortable and relaxing feel in the bedrooms. The remainder of the hotel displays a splendid Art Nouveau sense of decoration. The 1908 Lisboa Hotel is waiting for you!

1908 Lisboa Hotel
Largo do Intendente Pina Manique 6
1100-285 Lisboa

+351 21 880 4000

https://www.1908lisboahotel.com/

Rooms: from 150 EUR

content.title: LX Boutique Hotel, trendy elegance

introduction.small: Near the Tagus River, LX Boutique Hotel is a dream location to discover the white city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: LX Boutique Hotel, trendy elegance

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of the historic centre, at the crossroads of the Baixa, Ciado and Cais do Sodré districts, LX Boutique Hotel is ideally located for exploring Lisbon's iconic sites.
Behind the beautiful azure facade of this four-star centuries-old establishment, ancient charm meets modern comfort. Each of the four floors bears the name of a Lisbon neighbourhood, from Fado to Bairro Alto, which inspired the decoration of its 61 rooms. Each has a particular style: contemporary furniture and noble materials, walls painted in a variety of colours from soft green to deep blue… With a view overlooking the Tagus or a suite with a private terrace, you will seize every moment of the capital's atmosphere.
The LX is home to a renowned restaurant, the Confraria LX. In a large lounge dressed in velvet, enjoy the famous sushi revisited with fusion sauces, making it one of the best sushi bars in the capital. Another highlight of this establishment!

LX Boutique Hotel
Rua do Alecrim 12
1200-017 Lisboa

+351 21 347 4394

https://www.lxboutiquehotel.com/

Rooms: from 95 EUR

content.title: LX Factory, detour by the 25 de Abril Bridge

introduction.small: In the popular district of Alcantara, a vast industrial wasteland has been transformed into one of the key places in the Portuguese capital. Cultural and gourmet detour via LX Factory.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: LX Factory, detour by the 25 de Abril Bridge

paragraphs.text:
This is the story of a thread and fabric company who, in 1846, settled in Lisbon's Alcantara district. 23,000 sqm were dedicated to companies and professionals in the industry for several decades. The factory is now a hotspot for tourists, mixing fashion, culture and gastronomy.
Between exhibitions, open doors, flea markets, artistic conventions, performances and concerts, LXFactory gives Lisbon a most beautiful heartbeat: alongside walls covered with frescos by street artists, locals and travellers from around the world gather around art and the love of good food.
Bars and restaurants have set up shop, including the Landeau Chocolate pastry shop, The Burger Factory, and the famous Cantina Lx. In the latter, you will enjoy a cheap meal in an old warehouse decorated in retro and stylish manner: corrugated iron roofing, small glass panels, brick on the walls and large wooden tables. For less than EUR 15, snack on a few olives, enjoy a salad of beetroot, green beans, goat's cheese, rocket, orange and nuts, and end with a fruit medley. So healthy!

LXFactory
Rua Rodrigues de Faria 103
1300-501 Lisboa

+351 21 314 3399

https://lxfactory.com/en/homepage-en/

content.title: Inspira Santa Marta, Lisbon's zen address

introduction.small: From the rooms to the spa, the Inspira Santa Marta boutique hotel is a place entirely dedicated to your well-being, while keeping an eco-friendly stance

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Inspira Santa Marta, Lisbon's zen address

paragraphs.text:
Near the "Lisboan Champs Élysées", Santa Marta street unrolls its ribbon of cobbled sidewalks and old buildings, where the immaculate 18th century facade of the Inspira Santa Marta stands. Once inside, you are transported to a resolutely modern world. Upstairs, you immediately feel the tranquillity that emanates from the 89 rooms and suites, laid out according to feng shui principles. Modern and elegant furniture is spread out on golden oak floors, while in the bathroom, the shower is equipped with a system that saves water.
Echoing the ambient serenity, the spa, with its six treatment rooms, offers a wide range of relaxation techniques - massages, chromotherapy, hydrotherapy -, adapted to all your needs.
The hotel also has a gluten-free restaurant, the Open Brasserie Mediterrânica, with a menu inspired by Portuguese gastronomy that showcases organic, seasonal products. Inspira Santa Marta, very attached to sustainable development principles, certainly deserves the two awards it has received for its environmental commitment.

Inspira Santa Marta
Rua de Santa Marta 48
1150-297 Lisboa

+351 21 044 0900

https://www.inspirahotels.com/en/

Rooms: from 127 EUR

content.title: Gin Lovers, the exquisite aroma of a cocktail

introduction.small: Gin Lovers, the gathering of all gin lovers in a shop, ready to turn their passion into a profession and share. A look back on the history of alcohol

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gin Lovers, the exquisite aroma of a cocktail

paragraphs.text:
Invented in the 16th century by a certain Franciscus Sylvius, doctor and chemist of German origin, gin quickly won over the English who are often credited for its creation. Wheat, rye, malted barley or corn are gin's main ingredients, whose particular aroma comes from the addition of grains and juniper berries.
As indicated by its name, Gin Lovers is a bar 100% dedicated to this drink. Here, you can find over 60 different brands of gin - both Portuguese and international -, several types of "botanicals" (used for maceration) and mineral waters, to create a nearly infinite variety of combinations. To make this experience even more astonishing, the bar is located in an old palace in the Príncipe Real district, between Bairro Alto and Largo do Rato, whose decoration has been fully preserved. For the hottest evenings, Gin Lovers also has a beautiful terrace just next to the Botanical Garden, where you can also enjoy a selection of local delicacies, including a platter of pataniscas de bacalhau (salt cod fritters) or salmon ceviche.
Born from the dreams of Carlos Alves, Gin Lovers is now a reference in the preparation and sale of gin-based cocktails and for a good reason: the spirited ambition of the establishment's team takes them all over the world, from Copenhagen to San Francisco by way of Paris, Barcelona and Funchal.

Gin Lovers Bar & Restaurant
Praça do Príncipe Real 26
1250-184 Lisboa

+351 21 347 1341

ginlovers.pt

Cocktails: from 8 EUR

Menu: around 25 EUR

content.title: The best of both worlds at Tapisco

introduction.small: If you are hesitating between Portuguese and Spanish cuisine, why choose? This popular address among gourmet tapas aficionados offers the best of each!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The best of both worlds at Tapisco

paragraphs.text:
Contraction of "tapas" (appetiser) and "petiscos" (snack), Tapisco is a restaurant where there is strength in unity. Chef Henrique Sá Pessoa knows no boundaries when it comes to cooking, offering Portuguese and Spanish specialties on the house's menu. In the plate as in life, the two countries are friends. A myriad of small dishes will delight even the most demanding gastronomes... Here, Lisbon cod is paired with Iberian ham, and the bomba de Lisboa is as explosive as the patatas bravas.

As for drinks, another specialty inspired by the Iberian Peninsula creates a perfect pairing: lightly distilled vermouth accompanies delicacies, indoors or on the terrace, and is found in cocktails like the bold spicy Príncipe or wiser Old Fashion. A warm and welcoming restaurant, like the plates that stack around your table for an unforgettable tasting.

Tapisco
Rua Dom Pedro V 81
1250-093 Lisboa

+351 21 342 0681

https://www.tapisco.pt/lisboa_en.html

Tapas: from 5 EUR

content.title: The explosive experience at Mini Bar

introduction.small: At Mini Bar, you will find gastronomic cuisine, surprising flavours and a festive atmosphere you will love. Everything you need for a more than successful evening.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The explosive experience at Mini Bar

paragraphs.text:
Tonight, you will be served by chef José Avillez in a festive and casual setting. Originally opened inside the São Luiz Theatre in the Chiado area in 2014, Mini Bar moved to the Bairro do Avillez in 2020. In its new premises, decor with a retro touch from the 30s and 40s contrasts with the avant-garde cuisine. Although playful, it still requires special preparation and cooking techniques that the chef has perfectly mastered. In small portions, enjoy bites, tapas and mini-dishes and combine hitherto undreamed-of flavours.
Try the Algarve king prawn ceviche, croquetes in mustard mousse, cod marinated in strawberry vinegar and Thai-style sautéed bay scallops. The menu is made up of five miniature courses: a cocktail to bite into, snack, starter, fish, and meat. If you go there on a Friday or Saturday night, from 11 p.m. on, your evening will be hosted by a DJ.

Mini Bar
Bairro de Avillez
Rua Nova da Trindade 18
1200-303 Lisbon

+351 21 130 5393

https://www.minibar.pt/en/minibar-lisbon.html

Menu: from 39 EUR

content.title: Embaixada, the concept store not to be missed in Lisbon

introduction.small: Embaixada is THE store that any good local should be familiar with.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Embaixada, the concept store not to be missed in Lisbon

paragraphs.text:
Enter the ancient Ribeiro da Cunha Palace dating back to 1857, one of the most iconic buildings in the trendy Principe Real neighbourhood, where the Embaixada concept store has found its place, transforming the space into a mini shopping gallery that is both trendy and historical. The project has involved preserving the architectural heritage while customizing each boutique that houses several national brands and artists. Find yourself in an oriental-inspired setting, where twenty some small businesses focused on Portuguese design, craftsmanship, fashion, gastronomy, and culture follow one after another.
Discover a different universe in each room, conceived by numerous local gallery designers. You could spend an entire day there: from shoes, clothes, jewellery and furniture to organic products and cosmetics, you will be spoilt for choice. Also visit the exhibition area and enjoy a leisurely lunch at O Talho, a specialised meat restaurant located behind the shopping centre with a beautiful terrace inside a lush garden.

Embaixada
Praça do Príncipe Real 26
1250-184 Lisboa

+351 96 530 9154

https://www.embaixadalx.pt/

content.title: MAAT: when the sea harks back to the land

introduction.small: With its modern design and wavy roofing reminiscent of an UFO, the Museum of Art, Architecture and Technology welcomes you in the Belém district.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MAAT: when the sea harks back to the land

paragraphs.text:
On the banks of the Tagus River, a former power plant built in 1909 became Lisbon's Museu de Arte, Arquitetura e Tecnologia, or Museum of Art, Architecture and Technology (MAAT) in October 2016, offering 38,000 sqm of exhibition areas and art storerooms, as well as a restaurant. Designed by British architect Amanda Levete's studio, a futuristic wing has been added to the existing building and adorns the facades with white ceramic tiles. This organic architecture aims to restore the historical link between swaying pieces of land along the Tagus river and the sea, reflecting on the gallery's floor. To see the river from a whole new perspective, you can step out onto the museum's roof or take a walk in this contemporary building's adjacent park. In addition to the permanent collection on science and electricity, temporary exhibitions take an interest in various technological innovations, the revolution brought by electrical lighting being one. It also offers art collections from around the world.

MAAT

content.title: PARK, a gorgeous bar to admire the sunset

introduction.small: A relaxed rooftop bar if you ever saw one, situated on the roof of a car park.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: PARK, a gorgeous bar to admire the sunset

paragraphs.text:
Concept creators will go for anything to find most surprising and unusual ideas. Park your rental car and take the lift to the last floor. Then walk up the access ramp that leads to a rooftop bar that offers a 360° vista every bit as exceptional as the ones you would have in Singapore and Hong Kong's skyscrapers. A matter of metres away are the roofs of the Bairro Alto district, the Santa Catarina bell tower, and then in the distance the Tagus River and 25 de Abril bridge. Attracted by the scent of the best cocktails the city has to offer (to be enjoyed in moderation), sit comfortably in wooden chairs amid unexpected vegetation for such a high spot. When night falls, the city lights make for a breathtaking spectacle, to the sound of performances from some of the best DJs around. The night is on!

content.title: SEA ME, see you…

introduction.small: Get your fill of saltwater, as this marine address brings out the best of oceanic treasures

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: SEA ME, see you…

paragraphs.text:
Only a few steps from the Praça Luís de Camões in the heart of the Chiado, you will come across SEA ME, one of the most popular fish joints of the city. As you arrive, you will find it looking like a trendy concept store. When you are in, the restaurant welcomes you with relaxed atmosphere, contemporary decoration and wood furniture. The spirit of the sea is very much alive as you can admire the morning fish in the back of the room.
Kitchen wise, the chef will treat you to multiple choices: sushi, seafood platters, cooked or raw fish… fish enthusiasts will be pleased! Go for the crispy Caribbean tuna served with pineapple and mint tartare, the spicy salmon, cheese cream and panko (the Japanese breadcrumb coating) or the octopus, potatoes and greens. If you so desire, order directly in the kitchen and select your fish, accompanied with colourful and crunchy vegetables.

content.title: Admire Lisbon up high from Lisboa Pessoa Hotel

introduction.small: Less than five minutes away from Museu de São Roque and 200m from the Chiado, idleness and comfort await you at Lisboa Pessoa Hotel!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Admire Lisbon up high from Lisboa Pessoa Hotel

paragraphs.text:
Inspired by the life and canon of Fernando Pessoa, the great Portuguese writer and author of works including the Livro do Desassossego (The Book of Disquiet), Lisboa Pessoa Hotel is a real gem located in the heart of Lisbon. Not far from the Largo do Carmo, a small square that is home to both the famous ruins of the Carmo convent, and one of the writer's former homes, the hotel pays homage to the man who was born in Lisbon, and lived his entire life right here in the city.

Allusions to Pessoa are everywhere you look: from the reception to the 75 spacious rooms and library, which regularly hosts literary events and reading circles. Should you feel peckish, head for the rooftop Mensagem restaurant (a nod, of course, to the title of one of Pessoa's poetry collections). where you will find all kinds of refreshments and snacks. For those keen on sports, Lisboa Pessoa also offers a private gym. Make a stop there before slipping into your bedroom's marble tub for a well-deserved moment of relaxation. Why not also use it as opportunity to read (or reread) The Keeper of Sheep or Crónicas da Vida Que Passa?

introduction.small: A charming hotel of the Bairro Alto, Lisbon's nighttime district.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A Casa das Janelas Com Vista, live like a local

paragraphs.text:
Even though you are staying in Lisbon's festive neighbourhood, this 12-room capacity hotel is a little shelter where to enjoy peace and quiet. The living area and kitchen are shared, on the basis of a bed & breakfast. Spaces are pleasant and bright, and the small terrace is perfect for a chat with friends or simply to have a good time. The decoration is neat and trendy, like the white Eames chair in which you will rock. Each room enjoys a unique view - as the hotel's name suggests: Com Vista - and decoration: yellow table, hand-painted wardrobe, velvet padded chaise longue or good old armchairs, there is something for every taste. Bathrooms are roomy and scented with refreshing essences. This hotel oozes the joy of living and undeniably constitutes a very good starting point for an active stay.

content.title: Taberna da Rua das Flores: Essential

introduction.small: Nestled in an old grocery store in Chiado, the Taberna serves forgotten Portuguese cuisine. A canteen not to be missed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Taberna da Rua das Flores: Essential

paragraphs.text:
Nothing ostentatious in this small neighbourhood restaurant. The only possible drawback is the small crowd of Lisboans waiting for their tables outside, a glass in hand. For the Taberna does not take reservations. And for good reason. This popular restaurant has a dozen small tables along a corridor with minimalist décor where only the original tiles provide a touch of colour. The reason for this no-frills approach is because everything here happens on the plate. From classic lunch dishes to plates to share in the evening, the slate is renewed twice daily depending on the market and especially what fresh fish is available. Raw, marinated, half-baked, fried, and grilled, fish is, of course, the centrepiece. Traditional Portuguese recipes are enlivened by a very assured modernity. The same approach is taken with game and white meat served with herbs and a perfect use of spices.

introduction.small: At Café Vertigo, you will literally step back in time.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vertigo Café, artist's rendezvous

paragraphs.text:
A quiet spot to sip a coffee, play old board games, or simply pass the time watching the ships pass across the wall tiles. The atmosphere could not be friendlier. Let your mind wander amid the tables, gilt mirrors, painted woodwork, and complex geometric patterns on the ceiling. When you return to reality, an abundant menu of multiple choices awaits: teas, coffees, pastries, snacks, and light meals (savoury tarts, daily specials, salads). When the end of the day approaches, a joyous crowd fills the café. It is the ideal place to make friends and discover the bohemian residents of Chiado.

content.title: A Travessa, a restaurant in the middle of a convent

introduction.small: Occupying part of the Convento das Bernardas, A Travessa offers fine dining in many flavours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A Travessa, a restaurant in the middle of a convent

paragraphs.text:
Created in 1978, A Travessa is located near the old quarter of Madragoa and the aristocratic residences of Lapa (the embassy district), in the heart of the Bernadine Convent, which dates from the 17th century. For an intimate and contemplative atmosphere, book a table in one of the rooms of the old refectory, and sit down around the large fireplace, beneath a vaulted ceiling of red brick. The tables on the terrace, in the cloister, are the most romantic. In this unique setting and according to the chef's inspirations, enjoy grilled John Dory and monkfish, milk-fed lamb or sautéed foie gras. To finish, do not miss the prisco do abade, a traditional dessert made from egg yolks and sugar. A delight!

It is worth noting that the Bernadine Convent is also home to a remarkable puppet museum, the Museu da Marioneta, that visitors of all ages are sure to love. The entry is on Rua da Esperança.

content.title: Small boutique selection for a successful shopping trip in Lisbon

introduction.small: Chiado, Avenida da Liberdade, Príncipe Real: Lisbon is a window-shopping wonderland of trendy boutiques and fashion-forward addresses.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Small boutique selection for a successful shopping trip in Lisbon

paragraphs.text:
The Portuguese capital has no shortage of incredible shops, each one more surprising than the last.
First on your list, JNcQUOI (for Je-ne-sais-quoi, a certain something), a very contemporary concept-store that mixes fashion and gastronomy. This multi-dimensional experience over three sets of floors will bring you men's and women's fashion, tailoring service for men, a Ladurée area, a corner devoted to publications by Assouline , a restaurant, and a "DeliBar" for a quick lunch of lobster roll or grouper ceviche. A wine cellar and a deli round up the offer.

Wetani. is another multi-label shop, located behind the Mercado da Ribeira, a truly customised outlet with an edge when it comes fashion, but not only! You can also find handbags, decorative and vintage objects, tableware, jewellery and more.

Luvaria Ulisses, a tiny 15-sqm shop, is a must. Open since 1925, this shop features handmade leather gloves that the shop people will let you try on but only if you follow their very precise instructions.

In a diametrically opposed style is the Embaixada Concept Store, a mecca for stylish trendsetters with a great café, all housed in a former palace. All the hottest Portuguese brands are on display: limited edition women's clothing and accessories, custom jewellery and organic cosmetics.

Catarina Portas, a former journalist, is the founder of A Vida Portuguesa, which specialises in luxury Portuguese products: the best brands of scented soaps, famous Tricana sardine tins, books, and vintage trinkets.
If you are looking for candles, Casa das Vellas is the address of your dreams: they've been making handmade candles, including birthday candles, since 1789.

content.title: Hotel Britania: vestiges of Art Deco

introduction.small: Nestled in the historic heart of Lisbon, the Britania was designed by the famous Portuguese architect, Cassiano Branco.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Britania: vestiges of Art Deco

paragraphs.text:
As soon as you have stepped through the elegant arched gate, cross the hall loaded with chandeliers and tiles and introduce yourself at the stunning polished wooden desk, where the receptionist will offer you the key to one of the hotel's 33 rooms.
Surrounded by the white marble walls, black lacquer, chrome, and satin, you will feel instantly immersed in a world of Art Deco style: there is even an old barber shop, kept as a museum piece. The wood-lined lobby bar is the perfect place to enjoy a delicious cocktail by candlelight, comfortably seated on a plush sofa. The elegant lounge serves hearty American breakfasts. The evening, after an aperitif, is the time to wrest yourself free from this comfortable cocoon just long enough to dine in one of the many restaurants just steps away.

content.title: Jerónimos Monastery, a pure architectural marvel

introduction.small: A masterpiece of Gothic art, the monastery was built in the 16th century for the religious order of the Hieronymites

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jerónimos Monastery, a pure architectural marvel

paragraphs.text:
Commissioned by King Manuel I in 1502, the monastery was built in the Belém district on the site of an old chapel where, in 1497, Vasco da Gama said his prayers before leaving on his long voyage. The building took nearly a century to complete. A shrine for explorers, the monastery is full of maritime motifs rope wrapped around the columns and innumerable aquatic monsters recalling the period when Portugal ruled the oceans. The cloister, with its exceptional sculptures, is a favourite among visitors.

The lower floor, designed by French-born Portuguese architect Diogo de Boitaca, is an exuberant mix of Gothic and Renaissance styles. The top floor, meanwhile, is the work of masterful Iberian architect Juan de Castillo. Having miraculously survived the 1755 earthquake, the monastery is now listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. After your visit, head over to the Belém Tower just a short walk away to enjoy a stroll in the cool of the evening.

Mosteiro dos Jerónimos

+351 21 362 0034

https://www.patrimoniocultural.gov.pt/en/museus-e-monumentos/dgpc/m/mosteiro-dos-jeronimos/

content.title: Igreja de São Roque: a magnificent Baroque church

introduction.small: In the heart of the Alto, the São Roque church does not look like much from the outside, but the interior is a jewel of Baroque art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Igreja de São Roque: a magnificent Baroque church

paragraphs.text:
Built in the late 16th century, Lisbon's São Roque (Saint Roch) church belonged to the Society of Jesus and was for centuries the most important Jesuit church in the Portuguese-speaking world. Its story is particularly original because the São Baptista chapel, one of the main buildings, was designed in Rome, in Italian marble and materials, between 1742 and 1747. It was then transported by boat from Italy to Portugal to be reassembled, like a jigsaw puzzle, on its current location. The building's design, modelled on a Baroque style church-hall, is quite simple, but the interior is full of ornaments and contains many one-of-a-kind pieces. Take time to check out the paintings by Zurbaran and the reliquaries dating from the 14th to the 18th centuries.

The church's treasures have now been entrusted to the Santa Casa da Misericórdia charity, which exhibits most of them at the São Roque museum just next door.

Igreja de São Roque/ São Roque Museum

content.title: Gambrinus, tradition and delicacies

introduction.small: For more than 75 years, Gambrinus has been one of the top tables in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gambrinus, tradition and delicacies

paragraphs.text:
The restaurant takes its name from two sources: a unique blend of brown and blonde draft beer, and the patron saint of brewers. In 1964, the Portuguese architect Maurício de Vasconcelos gave the space a modern look, adding a huge stone fireplace at the back of the main hall, a stained-glass window bearing the image of the patron saint with beer in hand, and rare wood panelling on the walls.

Get cosy in the bar to sample a selection of Portuguese wines, or enjoy them in the dining room alongside a menu of quality seafood and local dishes, served late into the night: grilled meat and fish, Andalusian fried calamari, sole with capers and for dessert fresh mango mousse. The perfect spot to visit after an evening at the nearby Teatro Nacional Dona Maria II, one of the country's most prestigious theatres.

content.title: Fado: the music of saudade

introduction.small: For the Portuguese, fado is the song of melancholy and Clube do Fado remains undoubtedly the best place to make its discovery

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fado: the music of saudade

paragraphs.text:
For the Portuguese, only fado can recount life's greatest tales: stories of thwarted love, daily suffering, pervasive nostalgia, saudade, an untranslatable word that resonates to the rhythm of stringed instruments. Clube do Fado warmly invites newcomers to listen to the Portuguese guitar accompanying its mournful songs. The founder, the talented singer Maria da Fé, has opened a second and equally unique place, Sr. Vinho, where the best voices in the capital congregate.
Devotees listen intently to stunning melodies of melancholy while nibbling on simple, typical dishes like pataniscas de bacalhau with rice and beans, pepper steak, and grilled wreckfish, or they arrive slightly after 10:00 p.m. for a drink. The musicians change every 30 minutes, offering the public moments of authentic fado between two short breaks for conversation.

content.title: Memmo Alfama Hotel, an address you will keep as a secret!

introduction.small: The Memmo Alfama offers a 100% Portuguese world of quality products and brands for a complete immersion in the modern culture of the country.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Memmo Alfama Hotel, an address you will keep as a secret!

paragraphs.text:
Located in the picturesque Alfama district and featuring both a typical Lisbon patio of yore and a beautiful whitewashed facade, the Memmo Alfama dates back to the 19th century. A work by Portuguese artist Vhils on one of the exterior walls sets the tone. The lounge area is cosy and the concierge is a fount of information about local sights and attractions.

There are many books and much documentation available in a small space dedicated to the history of Lisbon. Neutral tones (beige, taupe and white) and wood are featured in the rooms. Located on the first floor, the Memmo Terrace Alfama has a red-coloured pool in striking contrast to the blue of the river, and the wine bar is the ideal place for a drink facing the Tagus. An ideal spot to catch a glimpse of the Portuguese art of living.

Memmo Alfama Hotel

content.title: Museu do Azulejo, a staple of Portuguese culture

introduction.small: The stunning setting of this old convent and its incredible mosaic collection are sure to please.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museu do Azulejo, a staple of Portuguese culture

paragraphs.text:
From the lightest to the darkest blue, azulejos, the local tiles decorated with patterns, are ubiquitous in Portugal, on the walls of buildings, inside houses... They tell the story of, and have left their mark on, the country's architecture and heritage. To understand all their intricacies, pay a visit to this gorgeous museum in the cloister of the former convent of Madre de Deus, founded in 1506. The 7,000 pieces, which come from Portugal but also the Arab world and Flanders, give an overview of the evolution of the ceramic tile art from the Renaissance to its adaptation of the most modern techniques. Give yourself time to admire the gigantic mural mosaic, nearly 25m long, of Lisbon before the giant earthquake of 1755.

Museu Nacional do Azulejo

content.title: Museu Berardo Colecção, be passionate about art

introduction.small: The Berardo Collection is the largest private collection in Europe.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museu Berardo Colecção, be passionate about art

paragraphs.text:
The collection of the businessman José Manuel Rodrigues Berardo is part of the Centro Cultural de Belém, a building of pared-down architecture that in just over two decades has become the symbol of Lisbon creativity and the city's growing influence. The galleries cover the great movements of Modern Art, from Surrealism to Pop Art, from Hyperrealism to Minimalism and Conceptualism. From Francis Bacon to Christian Boltanski, Jean Dubuffet, Nan Goldin, David Hockney, Andy Warhol, René Magritte, Picasso and Salvador Dalí, all the major artists of the 20th century are on display here. With more than 800,000 visitors each year, it is one of the only Portuguese Museums listed among the most visited in the world, as per The Art Newspaper. The cherry on top: this collection of 900 high-quality works is for you to admire... free of charge.

content.title: Museu Calouste Gulbenkian, a unique collection

introduction.small: In a residential area in the north of the city, this museum houses the vast collection of a 1930s oil tycoon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museu Calouste Gulbenkian, a unique collection

paragraphs.text:
Inaugurated in 1969, the museum was designed by three architects, Ruy Jervis d'Athouguia, Pedro Cid, and Alberto Pessoa, in homage to Calouste Gulbenkian, an Armenian businessman who wanted a place to show off his private art collection. Bequeathed to the Portuguese State after his death in 1955, the rooms are now part of a foundation bearing his name. Located in a green space, the Art Nouveau building is built entirely of poured concrete. Calouste Gulbenkian was able over the years to put together a very eclectic collection ranging from ancient Egyptian artefacts to modern pieces by Lalique; Flemish and Italian painting; 18th century objects of the French decorative arts, such as vases and ceramics; and naturalistic paintings. After having snacked in the museum café, you can also relax in the fabulous gardens.

Calouste Gulbenkian Museum

content.title: Lux Frágil: ideal stopover of Lisbon's nightlife

introduction.small: Set in a labyrinthine warehouse on the port, this nightclub, part-owned by American actor John Malkovich, is a paradise for night lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lux Frágil: ideal stopover of Lisbon's nightlife

paragraphs.text:
For nearly a quarter of a century, LuxFrágil has been the fashionable club of the Lusitanian capital: great music, chic and cosy atmosphere, and a beautiful modern décor in a renovated warehouse down by the river. With its maze of small rooms, mirrored walls, electric-blue lights, futuristic dance floors, and neon decor, LuxFrágil is an incredible ode to the pleasures of the senses. Immerse yourself in the relaxed atmosphere of the first floor, seated on a comfortable sofa amid a laid-back crowd. Later, get onto the crowded dance floor and move to the sounds of DJs from around the world. Finally, do not miss the sunrise over the Tagus from the roof terrace the perfect excuse to dance until dawn.

content.title: Panoramic viewpoints overlooking the city

introduction.small: On the hilltops of Lisbon, the many miradouros are great places to enjoy a glass of something while drinking in the panorama.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Panoramic viewpoints overlooking the city

paragraphs.text:
The Miradouro de Graça is one of the most romantic gazebos, with stunning views over São Jorge Castle and the Tagus. Miradouro São Pedro de Alcântara, located in the Príncipe Real street is the only one to offer a 180-degree view of the Alfama hill, São Jorge Castle, and Rossio Square.

The Miradouro das Portas do Sol is popular with party animals and those who love to see the sun rise above the rooftops of the capital. However, if the nocturnal life is not for you, during the day you can admire one of the best views of the Monastery of São Vicente da Fora and the church of Santo Estevão. Santa Catarina, with its kiosk converted into a café, is the city's "postcard" terrace. It is also known for its statue of the "Adamastor", in homage to the creature invented by the great Portuguese poet Luís de Camões, or Camoens, in his epic poem, The Lusiads.

content.title: Valverde Hotel: a charming gem with a lush patio

introduction.small: Just a few minutes' walk from the Botanical Garden, this boutique hotel surprises and delights for the quality of its hospitality and its refined decoration.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Valverde Hotel: a charming gem with a lush patio

paragraphs.text:
On six floors in a splendid 19th-century building, the Hotel Valverde offers no shortage of surprises. First, the impeccable hospitality of a young and dedicated staff that meets all needs with discretion and competence. The 25 rooms are decorated in a vintage style that blends perfectly with the more traditional Portuguese elements of the decoration. The projection room is a plus, as is the gym and outdoor heated pool with water jets. The patio, with its lush greenery and small heated pool overlooking the bustling Avenida da Liberdade, is an irresistibly peaceful haven - all the more so as it is home to the excellent Sítio Valverde restaurant. Here, chef Carla Sousa brings diners elegantly modern Portuguese cuisine, like braised wild sea bass with Alentejo bread soup and Bulhão Pato-style clams. Last - but by no means least - this welcome oasis of calm is located a matter of metres from the capital's grand Avenida da Liberdade.

content.title: Portugal, a surfer's paradise

introduction.small: Whether for first timers or hard-core veterans, surfing in Peniche or Ericeira is a real adventure.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Portugal, a surfer's paradise

paragraphs.text:
Portugal's pristine, untamed beaches attract lovers of surfing from around the globe. For beginners, the beach at Peniche is the best choice to live unforgettable sporting moments. The small fishing village of Ericeira, halfway between Lisbon and Peniche is a surfer's paradise. Foz do Lizandro, Praia do Sul, Matadouro, Furna these are the many names for the different spots that have made the area's reputation. The variety of waves accommodates different skill levels: you can surf right, left, or back of the wave. Helios Ericeira hotel offers a relaxing atmosphere and organizes surfing sessions. To see the biggest waves in the world, stop in Nazaré, where in 2017 the Brazilian surfer Rodrigo Koxa rode a 24-metre monster!

content.title: Torel Palace Lisboa, to feel like the queen of the day

introduction.small: Enjoy an intimate and charming stay in this historic residence.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Torel Palace Lisboa, to feel like the queen of the day

paragraphs.text:
You will feel right at home in this traditional house from the 19th century, which is accessed by the Elevador do Lavra, the oldest funicular in Lisbon, at Largo da Anunciada. The decor of each of the 25 rooms is inspired by a Portuguese queen (or a foreign queen, provided she lived in Portugal): Dona Catarina de Bragança, Dona Isabel, Dona Estefania…or by a king.

If you are looking to take your small family on holiday somewhere that offers all the comforts of home, the hotel has a villa for four people adjacent to the main building, equipped with a kitchenette and direct access to the pool. Do not miss the panoramic views of the river and Saint George's Castle from the Torel Palace Lisboa garden. Parrots sometimes make appearances in spring, squawking in the trees of the wonderful gazebo.

content.title: Teatro Nacional de São Carlos, Lisbon's main opera house

introduction.small: The building was designed by architect José da Costa e Silva at the end of the 18th century.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Teatro Nacional de São Carlos, Lisbon's main opera house

paragraphs.text:
Inspired by La Scala in Milan, the building's remarkable yellow façade was inaugurated in the historic Chiado neighbourhood on 30 July 1793 with a performance of Italian composer Domenico Cimarosa's La Ballerina Amante. Its interior, with its bluish tones, interspersed with green and gold, combines rococo and neoclassical styles and has exceptional acoustics. In the 19th century, when the royal family fled to Brazil following the invasion of Portugal by Napoleon Bonaparte's armies, the Teatro Nacional in Lisbon served as the model for Rio de Janeiro's own Teatro Nacional. Upon your arrival in Lisbon, book a balcony seat in this majestic hall, which holds more than a thousand spectators and where the memory of Maria Callas in La Traviata still hangs in the air. With a very eclectic programme ranging from classical works to a much more contemporary repertoire, you will inevitably find your happiness.

content.title: Palácio Ramalhete: their castle is your castle

introduction.small: If you dream of living in an 18th-century palace but with all the mod cons, this is the place for you.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Palácio Ramalhete: their castle is your castle

paragraphs.text:
The Palacio Ramalhete survived the great earthquake of 1755 with its glamour and old-world charm intact. The Dukes of Windsor, King Manuel II, and all the nobility and elite of European society have at one time or another enjoyed its tranquility. The decorative elements, from the azulejos on the walls to the coffered ceilings, are original and contribute to the timeless charm. The 12 renovated rooms and suites are each unique, combining contemporary comfort with taste, history, and authenticity. Pushing through an imposing wooden door gives access to three large, bright rooms where books on Portugal are laid out for your reading pleasure. Behind the building, a courtyard with many relaxation areas invites you to spend the afternoon. If you want to take some exercise, the pool awaits you above the gardens, where you can enjoy exceptional views over the Tagus. This is a paradise that you will have a hard time leaving.

content.title: Sintra, architecture and nature in perfect harmony

introduction.small: In 1995, UNESCO added Sintra to the Lists of Intangible Cultural Heritage, as the city offers a perfect balance between natural beauty and a rich historical setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sintra, architecture and nature in perfect harmony

paragraphs.text:
Just 30 km north of Lisbon, Sintra was built at the foot of the Serra de Sintra by members of the Portuguese nobility, who constructed fabulous palaces there and surrounded them with gardens of breathtaking beauty. The atmosphere of the city is right out of a fairy tale: the climate is often foggy and wet, and the palaces, in a myriad of very different styles, provide an almost tragic dimension. Do not miss the Pena National Palace, the first Romantic building in Europe. At the top of the Serra de Sintra, the Palace, designed by Wilhelm Ludwig von Eschwege, lord and friend of Prince Ferdinand of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, has a Walt Disney castle-like feel, with its many colours and its mixture of architectural styles Moorish, Baroque, and even Renaissance. Linger a little further at the Castle of the Moors, a large fortress built in the 8th century. Monserrate Palace, built in an Arabic style of the 19th century, offers a beautiful promenade through its 143-hectare park. If you get tired, stop in at the Tivoli Palácio de Seteais Sintra hotel for a gourmet break

content.title: Tágide and Tágide Wine and Tapas Bar: an exceptional view of Lisbon

introduction.small: In the heart of Chiado, a more casual alternative to the gourmet restaurant of the same name.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tágide and Tágide Wine and Tapas Bar: an exceptional view of Lisbon

paragraphs.text:
For more than 30 years, the Restaurante Tágide has served excellent Portuguese cuisine in a cosy atmosphere enhanced by large, blue-carpeted rooms, soft lighting, and small balconies opening onto the banks of the Tagus. Down on the ground floor, you can also enjoy the Tágide Wine & Tapas Bar.

The building was once part of the St Francis Convent, and several elements from this period still remain today, combined with tasteful 1950s decor. The bar also offers spectacular views over the rooftops of the capital. Enjoy delicious dishes in this welcoming and relaxed spot: the best options are the Portuguese tapas (petiscos) with scrambled eggs à la farinheira (sausage), Bulhão Pato clams or even stuffed breaded sardines, all accompanied by a masterful selection of Portuguese wines. A jazz band plays Friday nights, a perfect addition to the proceedings.

content.title: Olissippo Lapa Palace: the most opulent of Lisbon's palace hotels

introduction.small: A sublime hotel nestled in lush greenery slightly off the city centre, it is famous for its family atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Olissippo Lapa Palace: the most opulent of Lisbon's palace hotels

paragraphs.text:
Perched high above the city in the heart of the embassy quarter, the Olissippo Lapa Palace Hotel is a hotel benchmark. There are subtropical gardens and 100-year-old trees on the grounds of this former palace, which was built in the 19th century by the Marquis de Valencia. If you are sensitive to the historical dimension of places, choose one of 22 luxurious rooms decorated exactly as they were originally, with handcrafted copies of antique furniture and a natural colour palette accented with touches of gold. The view of the river from the terrace of Room 701 is breath-taking. Sip a cocktail under glittering chandeliers while ensconced in one of the red sofas of the Rio Tejo Bar before sampling the delicious Mediterranean cuisine at Lapa Restaurant - a parillada of fish and octopus with sweet potato purée, for example - or at the Pavillon Restaurant Bar if you are in the mood for something lighter. The outdoor pool is heated all year round.

content.title: Tramway: Climb aboard the yellow wagon and travel back in time

introduction.small: Explore the city aboard the Eléctrico 28, Lisbon's most famous tramline, which, for a century and a half, has run on its steep streets.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tramway: Climb aboard the yellow wagon and travel back in time

paragraphs.text:
No stay in Lisbon would be complete without a ride aboard the Eléctrico 28, the cute yellow tram you see everywhere. Virtually unchanged since 1873 when it was pulled by horses, riding the tram is an experience in itself and a great way to get up and down the hills to see the sights without wearing yourself out. Most of the cars still in circulation - the famous Remodelado - date all the way back to the 1930s. However, far from being consigned to museums, they are still in use today as the Line 28 route, with its hairpin turns and steep climbs, is simply not suitable for modern vehicles.

Its picturesque route takes in the Baixa, Graça, Alfama and Estrela districts. The Eléctrico 28 connects with most of Lisbon's major attractions, including the flea market, the Castle of São Jorge, and the Bairro Alto. It is the ideal way to explore the city in true comfort - just like a local.

content.title: Museu Nacional dos Coches: a magical visit for all ages

introduction.small: Come discover one of the largest collections of carriages in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museu Nacional dos Coches: a magical visit for all ages

paragraphs.text:
Located, since its inception, on the banks of the Tagus in a former armoury of the Royal Palace of Belém, this is one of the oldest museums in the city. It was inaugurated in 1905 by Queen Amélie of Orléans, wife of King Charles I, who wanted a place to keep the horse-drawn carriages and coaches of the Portuguese royal family. The building is a treasure trove, with gorgeous paintings and azulejos on the walls, and an exquisite indoor arena where horses were trained, and equestrian shows were held. Picture yourself driving one of these magnificent vehicles (coaches, sedans, cars, trucks, litters, sedan chairs), dating from the 17th century until the advent of the automobile. In May 2015, part of the museum was relocated 250 metres away and housed in an ultramodern building designed by Pritzker Prize-winning Brazilian architect Paulo Mendes da Rocha. Make sure you get time to visit at least one of the sites: be it the old or the new, each is beautiful in its own, wonderful way.

content.title: Museu Nacional de Arte Antiga: classical Portuguese art museum

introduction.small: One of the most famous museums in Lisbon, as much for its size as the quality of its collections.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museu Nacional de Arte Antiga: classical Portuguese art museum

paragraphs.text:
In the beautiful district of Lapa, the Museu Nacional de Arte Antiga is installed inside a 17th century palace that belonged to the Pombal family, until its transformation into a museum in the 1880s. As richly endowed with paintings as religious and decorative arts, it magnificently lays out the milestones of Portuguese art. Besides a rich collection of Portuguese and Dutch primitives, a section is devoted to 15th to 19th-century furniture and the masterworks of Portuguese medieval and Baroque goldsmiths. The famous polyptych The Adoration of St. Vincent painted by Portuguese artist Nuno Gonçalves between 1460 and 1470 is just one of the masterpieces on display, and it is considered to be on par with The Temptation of St. Anthony by Hieronymus Bosch, one of the most prominent figures of the Early Netherlandish painting school.

content.title: Altis Belém Hotel and Spa: riverfront designer destination

introduction.small: A five-star boutique hotel overlooking the port of Belém, whence set out Portugal's great explorers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Altis Belém Hotel and Spa: riverfront designer destination

paragraphs.text:
The Altis Belém, exceptionally well located on the banks of the Tagus, offers modern accommodations in the heart of a historic district. Design fans will admire its very contemporary line, sober and elegant rooms, and towering bay windows. The 50 rooms and suites are white, from the walls to the immaculate sheets and avant-garde furniture. The Michelin-starred Feitoria Restaurante & Wine Bar has hundreds of wines on offer, from the classic to the most exotic, as well as the best of the local vintages. Chef João Rodrigues takes inspiration from traditional Portuguese cuisine. The 1,000-square-metre BSpa by Karin Herzog with its indoor pool and steam room is particularly tempting, as is the hotel's Gastrobar 38° 41', famous for its DJ-driven Sunset Sessions, which always attract a cool crowd.

content.title: Carmo Convent, home of the Archaeological Museum

introduction.small: The roof of this striking medieval building close to the Chiado, has been in ruins since the 1755 earthquake.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Carmo Convent, home of the Archaeological Museum

paragraphs.text:
The ruins of the church and convent of the Carmelites are a remnant of this outstanding Gothic monument, with the roof having collapsed during the terrible earthquake that occurred on November 1, 1755. The convent was founded by Nuno Álvares Pereira in 1389 to house the Carmelite brothers of Moura. The institutions of the city have always wanted to keep the buildings in their ruined state in order to show the effects of the violent earthquake that shook the entire region. The church now houses the Archaeological Museum of Lisbon. The main exhibits are from the Palaeolithic and Neolithic periods, and the site - an “open-air” museum in the truest sense of the word – is home to medieval sarcophagi, Roman and Visigoth objects, and even Peruvian mummies. In the spring, classical music concerts are held under the jacarandas. This place holds a symbolic place in the history of the country for another reason: the Carmo square at the foot of the monastery is where the Portuguese ended the Salazar dictatorship during the Carnation Revolution of 1974.

Carmo Convent

content.title: Cascais, a former fishing port becomes a cosmopolitan hotspot

introduction.small: Just 25 km away from the city centre, this small coastal city, with its typical port, makes for an excellent day trip or overnight getaway.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cascais, a former fishing port becomes a cosmopolitan hotspot

paragraphs.text:
In the 19th century, Cascais became, like Estoril, a fashionable summer destination, and luxury homes housed the glamorous crowds who thronged there. In the 20th century, enthralled by its wild beaches and lively atmosphere, European royal families turned it into a kind of Portuguese Riviera. This sealed the fate of Cascais. The charm of the small town, however, is intact today: the centre has kept its ancient atmosphere and has many monuments to offer besides the splendid citadel and iconic lighthouse (especially Paula Rego's House of Stories and the bright pink Cascais Cultural Centre).

After a look around the town, a visit to the superb nearby beaches is a must: if you head east towards Lisbon, they are family-friendly and perfect for lounging in the sunshine, whilst to the north they are wilder, and popular with surfers and fans of crashing waves. Another way to enjoy the coastline is to hire a bicycle and ride from Cascais to Praia do Guincho. In the evening, head to O Pescador, a must-visit for seafood lovers. The rustic decor and warm, friendly atmosphere at this former fisherman's lodge is accompanied by a menu featuring dishes such as Mozambique-style prawns with ginger and Malagueta chili peppers, or grilled local octopus with new potatoes.

After a long day exploring, the Grande Real Villa Itália Hotel & Spa is a wonderful place to rest and recharge your batteries, complete with stunning views across the bay. Located in the former residence of Umberto II, the last King of Italy, this 5-star hotel is home to 124 luxury rooms and suites, three penthouses, and Real Spa Therapy, where you will find a selection of premier treatments.

Before enjoying a fabulous night's sleep, however, there is one thing left to do: discover the Boca do Inferno (“Hell's Mouth”), at the town's southernmost tip. This part of the cliff owes its name to the arch that the waves crash through, as well as the hair-raising noise it makes when the ocean is raging. Watching the sunset with the Boca do Inferno roaring in the background is a scene worth of the very best Hollywood films!

content.title: Comporta and its beautiful beaches

introduction.small: Only an hour from Lisbon, Comporta is the refuge of the bohemian jet set.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Comporta and its beautiful beaches

paragraphs.text:
A turquoise sea, powerful surf, white sand, ochre cliffs, rice fields behind the dunes, white and blue houses with thatched roofs... and nobody in sight. Welcome to the Alentejo coast, between Comporta and Melides. Strict town planning laws have helped keep the 70km coastline and its villages intact.
Once a secret paradise, the Comporta region has become, over the years, the hideout of discrete but influential personalities like Christian Louboutin and the designers Jacques Grange and Philippe Starck.
Take a break at the São João restaurant open year-round and enjoy typical and family dishes that perfectly blend the city's various specialities: fish, seafood and rice. Also note that galloping on the beach at sunset is a dream made possible by José Ribeira, who will show you the area's glorious vistas on horseback.

content.title: The Alfama district, by buggy or Ape Calessino

introduction.small: Bairro Alfama is Lisbon's most popular and colourful district. It is well worth an unusual kind of tour, in an equally unusual vehicle.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Alfama district, by buggy or Ape Calessino

paragraphs.text:
The best way to tour Lisbon, and particularly Bairro Alfama, without getting too tired is in a rented vehicle - it is not known as “the city of seven hills” for nothing! The most enjoyable options are the magnificent red 'buggy' (a lightweight electric all-terrain vehicle) and the fabulously retro Ape Calessino motorised tricycle. The buggy is ideal for a family of four you can roam the city without any problem, and even take on the steepest roads. While you are up there, admire the Alfama in all its splendour and understand why it is considered the most authentic area of Lisbon: narrow cobbled streets, bright facades, laundry hanging from the windows... And finally, for those who love to circulate everywhere, absolutely everywhere, there is the Segway solution: 100% ecological and 100% fun.

content.title: Belcanto and its gifted chef

introduction.small: Young, handsome, and Michelin-starred chef José Avillez is reinventing and elevating traditional Portuguese cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Belcanto and its gifted chef

paragraphs.text:
After highly acclaimed stints with Eric Frechon at Le Bristol Paris and star Spanish chef Ferran Adrià, José Avillez took over Belcanto on the Largo de São Carlos in the historic Baixa district in 2011. His forte is Portuguese gastronomy reinvented and modernised by molecular techniques. But nothing is overplayed. The two cosy rooms overlook the kitchen. Each dish is a gustatory journey you will not soon forget, starting with the exotically named amuse-bouches: Ginginha Abbey, Olive XL-LX, Lupin ... A choice of " Evolução " and " Belcanto " menus follows. Emphasis is on using seasonal ingredients, most often paired with classic elements like sea bass and alfonsino. Avillez is most definitely a name you have not heard the last of!

content.title: Bairro Alto Hotel: elegance meets contemporary luxury

introduction.small: This hotel has many assets, especially its beautiful roof terrace with stunning views of the city and river.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bairro Alto Hotel: elegance meets contemporary luxury

paragraphs.text:
In the steep, narrow streets of Bairro Alto (literally "upper district"), the heart of the artistic and bohemian area of the capital's old town, the Bairro Alto hotel is the ideal starting point for visiting the nearby Baroque churches. Housed in an 18th-century building typical of the neighbourhood, the hotel's 55 rooms overlook either the Tagus or the city. Each is attentively furnished with local furniture and objects in a refined decor.

Climb to the fifth floor to find the BAHR Restaurant & Bar, a place that exudes the bohemian vibes of the city's most influential artists. There, you will get to enjoy the very best of Portuguese fine dining with dishes created by chef Nuno Mendes, who was awarded a Michelin star during his time in London. Whether you are here for dinner or just a cocktail, it really is a sight to behold: the terrace is one of the most romantic places in Lisbon and offers a breath-taking view.

content.title: Cervejaria Ramiro, running in the family

introduction.small: Open since 1956, this family restaurant specialises in exceptional seafood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cervejaria Ramiro, running in the family

paragraphs.text:
Just a few minutes' walk from the Miradouro da Senhora do Monte lookout point where you can enjoy incredible panoramic views of the city, this landmark of Lisbon cuisine spans three floors of a building in the popular area of Martim Moniz. Lobsters and prawns in giant aquariums are on view on the usually noisy ground floor, while the calmer first floor room is decorated in a more intimate spirit, but still with a prevalent maritime theme.

For starters, the liveried waiters will suggest pata negra or other excellent Portuguese and Spanish hams. Order the house specialty: perfectly cooked mussels, shrimp, crab, langoustines or prawns with garlic all accompanied by Sagres, an excellent local beer. For big crowds or birthdays, a private room is available.

content.title: Albergaria Senhora do Monte: for gorgeous views of Lisbon

introduction.small: A small boutique hotel on a hill in the Graça neighbourhood, with a spectacular view of Lisbon and the river.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Albergaria Senhora do Monte: for gorgeous views of Lisbon

paragraphs.text:
Just two minutes' walk from the stunning 1.7-hectare Jardim da Cerca da Graça hillside park, this intimate address has a major asset: the garnet-tiled terrace affords a 360° view of the city, from Saint George's Castle to the shores of the river. Located on the highest hill of the city, the Albergaria Senhora do Monte is a pleasant, peaceful spot that never seems to change. The 28 rooms retain their original 1960s décor. There is no designer furniture, nor trendy decorative elements it is as if time has stood still. If you have the opportunity, book Room Four: its large corner balcony has the best view. In the morning, enjoy the hearty breakfast served on the terrace. After that, all that is left to do is hop in one of the famous yellow trams on Line 28 to head off and explore the city - the closest stop is no more than a stone's throw from the hotel.

content.title: Castelo de São Jorge, royalty has to be earned

introduction.small: Overlooking Lisbon, this splendid Moorish castle offers an incomparable panorama.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Castelo de São Jorge, royalty has to be earned

paragraphs.text:
The castle entrance is in the Alfama district, but to enter the building and merit the view, one has to climb, climb, and climb some more. A stronghold turned royal palace, the Castelo de São Jorge (St. George's Castle) stands on top of the hill of the same name. Its impenetrable walls protected the medieval city. Built by the Visigoths in the 5th century, it was appropriated and expanded by the Moors in the 9th century. The ramparts are made of 12 gates and 18 towers that overlook the city. The 1775 earthquake caused extensive damage and it was not until 1938 that the dictator António Salazar undertook to rehabilitate the Castelo. Spend some time relaxing in its shady gardens, a charming haven of peace and coolness in this oh-so-bustling capital. And there, from the top of the fortified wall, enjoy a panorama like no other onto both the Tagus and Lisbon's centre.

Castelo de São Jorge
Rua de Santa Cruz do Castelo
1100-129 Lisboa

content.title: Pastéis de Belém, an institution

introduction.small: Very close to the Jeronimos Monastery is the Pastéis de Belém, 'the' pastry shop of Lisbon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pastéis de Belém, an institution

paragraphs.text:
Hundreds of pastelarias dot the streets of Lisbon, and locals stop in at all hours to sample the delicious pastries. However, it was at the Pastéis de Belém in the early 19th century that monks first began to make their livelihood by selling small pastry flans of the same name). The recipe, a jealously guarded secret, has been passed from master baker to master baker for generations. To eat properly, sprinkle your still-warm-from-the-oven flan with a little cinnamon and icing sugar. To avoid long queues, do not visit during peak hours (between noon and 4 p.m.). When you arrive, feel free to come straight in: just find a table, sit down, and a waiter will take your order. Bom apetite!

Last but not least, it is worth noting that this is the only place that makes true pastéis de Belém. Elsewhere, you will find pastéis de nata: these are not the same as the pastries that this family-run bakery has been making for almost two whole centuries.
